understanding.p: The default SPFE build file (spfe-rules.xml) implements a standard order of build steps which will work for most topic sets. However, sometimes you will want to insert additional steps into the build, particularly at the synthesis stage. If you have a complex process at any stage of the build, it is better to break it up into multiple steps, each of which does one thing, and which produces an XML file to be read by the next stage of the build.

planning-question.planning-question-title: Do I need to change the build order?

planning-question-body.p: The default build order invokes a single build file for the synthesis, presentation, format, and encode stages. If you want to break any of these stages up into multiple steps, you will need to change the build order.

The most common reason for changing the build order is to do custom processing of source files to create topics, or to combine externally sourced material with authored material to produce topics. You would then run a regular or custom synthesis step on the resulting topic files.

doing.p: To change the build order, you write an ant rules file describing the steps of your build. You don't have to describe the complete build order in your build file. You can import spfe-rules.xml into your build file and then override the rules you want to change. To make this easier, spfe.rules defines an intermediate taget for each build step that has a dependency on the main build rules for that step. Rather than overriding the main build rule, you can just override the intermediate rule and add your custom rules to its dependency list.

The main build targets have names starting with two hyphens. For instance, the main synthesis rules is called --build.synthesis. The intermediate build rules have the same name starting with one hyphen, for instance, -build.synthesis. The -build.synthesis rule contains just a dependency on the main build rule, so in spfe.rules the -build.synthesis rule looks like this:
To override this rule and insert a build step before the main synthesis step, you write a build rules file like this:
doing.codeblock:
<project name="my-custom-build-rules" basedir="." default="draft">
<import file="${SPFEOT_HOME}/1.0/build-tools/spfe-rules.xml"/>
<target name="-synthesis" depends="--my-custom-synthesis-rule, --build.synthesis">
<target name="--my-custom-synthesis-rule"> <!-- your build rules here --> </target> </project>
doing.p: This build rule causes your custom synthesis rule to be called first, and then the standard synthesis rule. Obviously, if you do this you must create XML output in the place the default synthesis rule expects to find it. Alternatively, you can omit the default synthesis rule entirely, in which case your custom synthesis rule must create a syntheis XML document or documents in the place the presentation rule expects to find it.
